organizationName: GENERAL JOHN J PERSHING MEMORIAL HOSPITAL
chiefComplaint: Newborn with visible cervical spinal defect and enlarged head noted at birth.
presentIllness:
The patient is a term neonate born via spontaneous vaginal delivery after an uncomplicated labor. Prenatal ultrasound at 20 weeks gestation revealed a cervical myelomeningocele and ventriculomegaly, consistent with neural tube defect and associated hydrocephalus. No other anomalies were reported on fetal imaging. The pregnancy was otherwise uneventful, and maternal serologies were negative.
At birth, the infant was noted to have an open spinal defect in the cervical region, covered with a thin membrane, without evidence of CSF leakage. Head circumference was above the 97th percentile, and anterior fontanelle appeared full. Postnatal MRI confirmed a cervical myelomeningocele with associated hydrocephalus and Chiari II malformation.
Neurological examination demonstrated upper-limb weakness with decreased spontaneous movement and diminished tone in both arms, while lower extremity tone and reflexes were within normal limits. No signs of respiratory distress were observed. The infant is currently stable on room air and awaiting neurosurgical evaluation for closure of the defect and CSF diversion.
reasonForVisit: Evaluation and management of cervical myelomeningocele with associated hydrocephalus identified on prenatal imaging.
pastMedicalHistory:
Prenatal findings: Cervical myelomeningocele and ventriculomegaly detected on routine ultrasound at 20 weeks gestation.
Maternal history: No gestational diabetes, hypertension, or infections reported. Maternal serologies negative. No teratogenic exposures documented.
Birth history: Term infant, spontaneous vaginal delivery, Apgar scores 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively. No resuscitation required.
Postnatal imaging: MRI confirmed cervical myelomeningocele with associated hydrocephalus and Chiari II malformation.
Current status: No prior surgeries or interventions. Awaiting neurosurgical repair and CSF diversion.
reviewOfSystems:
General: No fever, no lethargy reported. Feeding adequately.
Head/Neck: Macrocephaly noted; anterior fontanelle full but soft. Prenatal and postnatal imaging confirmed ventriculomegaly.
Eyes: No abnormal eye movements; pupils equal and reactive.
Ears/Nose/Throat: No nasal congestion or discharge.
Cardiovascular: No cyanosis, no murmurs reported.
Respiratory: No respiratory distress or apnea episodes.
Gastrointestinal: Feeding tolerated; no vomiting or abdominal distension.
Genitourinary: Normal urine output.
Musculoskeletal: Upper limb weakness observed; lower limbs move spontaneously.
Neurological: Decreased tone and spontaneous movement in upper extremities; lower extremities normal. No seizures observed.
Skin: Cervical myelomeningocele present, covered with thin membrane; no signs of infection.
labTest2Name: Glomerular filtration rate [Volume Rate/Area] in Serum, Plasma or Blood by Creatinine-based formula (CKD-EPI)/1.73 sq M
plannedMed1Instructions: Take 1 tablet daily with food for nutritional support during neural tube defect management
vaccine1Name: Hepatitis B vaccine, pediatric or pediatric/adolescent dosage
currentProc1Name: Creation of shunt; ventriculo-peritoneal, -pleural, other terminus
currentProc2Name: Magnetic resonance imaging of the spinal canal and contents, cervical; without contrast material
disabilityType: Spina bifida - congenital neural tube defect
outbreakDetails: No current outbreak or emergency situation related to this case
